Advanced Ceramics Research Center Nagoya Institute of Technology 10-6-29 Asahigaoka Tajimi Gifu 507-0071 Japan Graphical abstract A similarity of catalytically active sites for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) and NO decomposition was investigated. Y2O3 prepared by different methods showed the activity for both reactions. However, no good correlation between the C2 (C2H6 and C2H4) yield for the OCM reaction and the NO decomposition activity was observed. Since the disagreement of the catalytic activity for both reactions was suspected to be due to the non-uniform surface morphological properties of Y2O3, detail experiments were performed for Ba-doped Y2O3 catalysts. It was noteworthy that the addition of Ba into Y2O3 prepared by precipitation method caused a significant increase in not only the C2 yield for the OCM reaction but also the NO decomposition activity. The order of the C2 yield for the OCM reaction over Ba/Y2O3 with different Ba loading was in good agreement with that for the NO decomposition, suggesting the similarity of the active sites for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. XRD, FT-IR spectroscopy following methanol adsorption and 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction revealed that the oxygen-deficient Y3+ sites interacting strongly with Ba play a beneficial role in O2 activation, leading to the activation of CH4 and NO molecules to form intermediate in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. Keywords Oxidative coupling of methane NO decomposition Barium-doped yttrium oxide 16O/18O isotopic exchange 1 Introduction Methane, which is the main constituent of natural gas, is an abundant hydrocarbon resource for energy and chemicals. Among the methane conversion technologies to the chemicals, oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is regarded as energy efficient and simple chemical process for the production of higher hydrocarbons, especially, ethane and ethylene [1]. The development of highly active OCM catalyst has been continuously performed over the past few decades [2–4] since the pioneering works of Keller and Bhasin [5] and Hinsen and Baerns [6]. The OCM reaction proceeds via the formation of methyl (CH3·) radicals formed by the reaction of methane with active oxygen species and subsequent coupling the methyl radicals [7]. Methane is, however, the most stable hydrocarbon, leading to the difficulty of its selective activation to form CH3· radical intermediate, so that designing the catalyst surface to create the active oxygen species such as O–, O2 2– and O2– for the OCM reaction must be the important strategy to develop highly active catalysts. As for the initial work, Lunsford et al. clarified the participation of O– species formed on [Li+O–] center in the formation of methyl radicals for the OCM reaction over Li/MgO [8,9]. Buyevskaya et al. [10] investigated the isotopic oxygen exchange reaction over Sm2O3/MgO under the transient conditions, and revealed that the oxygen activation on the surface is faster than activation of methane and the surface oxygen species, *O(s), formed via dissociative adsorption, are highly reactive toward methane activation. The research group of Baerns et al. [11,12] has recently analyzed past catalytic data on the OCM reaction in order to gain new insights into the composition of high-performance catalysts. They revealed that all oxides of the selected elements, which positively affect the selectivity to C2 products, show strong basicity, and that binary and ternary oxides showing high performance are mainly based on Mg and La oxides. Alkaline (Cs, Na) and alkaline earth (Sr, Ba) metals are also effective dopants to increase the C2 selectivity of the host oxides. Okabe et al. [13] reported a good correlation between the surface basicity and C2 selectivity for the OCM reaction over SrO-La2O3 catalysts, where the surface basicity was correlated with the binding energy difference between La 3d and O 1 s levels of the catalysts. The productivity of the catalytic systems composed of basic oxides seems to be attributed to the availability of oxygen vacancies and/or other defects as active sites, which are important for oxygen activation [14–16]. Boreskov [17] measured the catalytic activity of the 4th period transition metal oxides for various catalytic reactions such as NO decomposition, methane oxidation and hydrogen oxidation, and revealed a distinct similarity in the change of a specific catalytic activity of metal oxides with respect to the above reactions. This may be due to the similarity of an essential contribution to the energy of an active complex, in this case, active oxygen species. The catalyst showing the activity for one reaction may also be effective for other reaction, if the characteristics of catalytically active sites for each reaction are similar. We have extensively studied the catalytic activity of Ba-doped Y2O3 for the direct decomposition of NO, and revealed the close correlation between the surface basicity and the catalytic activity of Ba/Y2O3 [18–21]. In accordance with the case of the OCM reaction, oxygen vacancies and/or other defects related to the surface basicity were suggested to act as active sites in NO decomposition. On the basis of in situ FT-IR spectroscopy and isotopic transient kinetic analysis, a reaction scheme in which NO2– intermediate can be formed via the activation of NO molecule with active oxygen species created on basic site was proposed [21–23]. A similar role of basic sites in Ba-doped C-type cubic Y2O3-ZrO2 for NO decomposition was also reported by Tsujimoto et al. [24]. It can be expected that the active catalysts for NO decomposition are also active for the OCM reaction. In this study, we particularly addressed Y2O3-based catalyst, which shows the activity for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions [18,25–27], and then investigated the similarity of catalytic performance of Ba-doped Y2O3 for both reactions. We also performed 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction to understand the difference in the catalytic performance of Ba-doped Y2O3. We want to propose new insights into the strategy for producing the OCM catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Y2O3 A plural Y2O3 catalyst was prepared by precipitation, reverse precipitation, homogeneous precipitation and hydrothermal methods. The details of Y2O3 catalysts prepared in the present study are summarized in Table 1 . (A) (A) Precipitation method (Y2O3(P)): To an aqueous solution of yttrium(III) nitrate (Y(NO3)3·6H2O, Wako Pure Chemical Industries) was added an aqueous solution of ammonia (10% NH4OH, Wako Pure Chemical Industries) as a precipitation agent at room temperature. The precipitate thus obtained was washed with distilled water, followed by drying and calcination at 600 °C for 5 h in air. (B) Reverse precipitation method (Y2O3(RP)): To an aqueous solution of ammonia as a precipitation agent was added an aqueous solution of yttrium(III) nitrate at room temperature. The precipitate thus obtained was washed with distilled water, followed by drying and calcination at 600 °C for 5 h in air. (C) Homogeneous precipitation method (Y2O3(HP)): The precipitation of yttrium hydroxide was obtained by adding urea (CO(NH2)2, Wako Pure Chemical Industries) to an aqueous solution of yttrium(III) nitrate and stirring at 90 °C for 24 h, and then washed with distilled water, followed by drying and calcination at 600 °C for 5 h in air. (D) Hydrothermal method (Y2O3(HT)): The oleate solution prepared by dissolving potassium oleate (C17H33COOK, 19% solution, Wako Pure Chemical Industries) with distilled water was added to an aqueous solution of yttrium(III) nitrate at room temperature under vigorously-stirred condition, followed by addition of ammonia aqueous solution. The mixture solution thus obtained was transferred to a Teflon vessel and then treated at 200 °C for 48 h in an autoclave. The product thus obtained was washed with distilled water, followed by drying and calcination at 600 °C for 5 h in air. 2.1.2 Ba-doped Y2O3 Ba-doped Y2O3 was prepared by impregnating Y2O3 powder, which was obtained by precipitation method as mentioned above, with an aqueous solution of barium(II) nitrate (Ba(NO3)2, Wako Pure Chemical Industries), followed by drying and calcination at 600 °C for 5 h in air. The loading of Ba was changed from 0.5 to 15 wt%. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Rigaku MiniFlex diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 30 kV and 15 mA. The scanning was done from 2θ = 15–65 º at a speed of 1 deg min−1. The BET surface area of the catalysts was determined by N2 physisorption at liquid nitrogen temperature using a BELSORP mini-II, after evacuating the samples at 300 °C for 1 h. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of adsorbed methanol as a probe molecule were taken to characterize the coordination status of surface Y3+ cations. A self-supporting sample disk of about 20 mg cm-2 placed in an IR cell with CaF2 windows was first activated at 600 °C for 1 h with oxygen at 40.0 kPa and then evacuated at 600 °C for 2 h. The activated sample was exposed to 0.67 kPa of methanol at room temperature, and then evacuated at the same temperature for 5 min. IR spectra were recorded at room temperature by using a JASCO FT/IR 4200 spectrometer at a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement The catalytic activity for oxidative coupling of methane and NO decomposition reactions was evaluated using a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. (A) Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM): The reaction gas composed of 44.4% CH4 and 11.1% O2 diluted with He as the balance gas was fed to a 0.1 g catalyst that had been pretreated in situ in a flow of He at 650 °C for 2 h at a rate of 45 cm3 min−1. The reaction temperature was increased from 650 to 750 °C in steps of 50 °C, and the steady-state catalytic activity was measured at each temperature. (B) NO decomposition: The reaction gas composed of 1% NO with He as the balance gas was fed to a 0.1 g catalyst that had been pretreated in situ in a flow of He at 600 °C for 2 h at a rate of 50 cm3 min−1. The reaction temperature was increased from 600 to 800 °C in steps of 50 °C, and the steady-state catalytic activity was measured at each temperature. The effluent gas for both reactions was analyzed with the use of on-line gas chromatograph equipped with TCD and FID as a detector (Shimadzu GC-2014ATTF) using a Molecular Sieve 13X column (for analysis of O2, N2, CH4 and CO), a Porapak QS column (for analysis of N2O and CO2) and a DC-200 (20%)/Shimalite column (for analysis of C2H4 and C2H6). 2.4 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction The 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction was carried out in a flow reactor system. An adequate amount of the sample (30 mg) was installed in a quartz reactor, and then pretreated in a flow of 5% O2/He at 600 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 100 °C in flowing 5% O2/He, the sample was purged with He at 100 °C for 30 min. The reaction gas composed of 1% 18O2/He was fed to the catalyst at a rate of 20 cm3 min−1, and then the temperature was increased up to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The masses of 32 (16O2), 34 (18O16O) and 36 (18O2) were continuously monitored by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (PFEFFER OminiStar). 3 Results 3.1 OCM performance of Y2O3 Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Y2O3 prepared by different method. Distinct XRD peaks indexed to the cubic phase of Y2O3 were observed for all the samples (Fig. 1). The width of XRD peaks due to Y2O3 was found to be different depending on the preparation method, indicating the difference in the crystallite size of Y2O3. Table 1 summarizes the crystallite size, which was calculated from the XRD peak due to the (222) plan (2θ = 29.1°) using Scherrer’s equation, and the BET surface area of Y2O3. Y2O3(HT) prepared by hydrothermal method was found to consist of small Y2O3 crystallites, and the crystallite size increased in the order of Y2O3(HT) < Y2O3(P) < Y2O3(HP) ∼ Y2O3(RP). On the other hand, the largest BET surface area was achieved for Y2O3(P). The order of the BET surface area is not in agreement with that of the crystallite size. The surface area of Y2O3(P) and Y2O3(RP) evaluated from the crystallite size was found to be 93.8 and 73.6 m2 g−1, respectively, which are relatively in good agreement with the BET surface area, suggesting that Y2O3(P) and Y2O3(RP) mainly consist of Y2O3 crystallites. On the other hand, the BET surface area of Y2O3(RP) and Y2O3(HT) was much smaller than the surface area evaluated from the crystallite size. Y2O3 particles might be composed of aggregated Y2O3 crystallites, leading to the formation of less-porous structure. Figs. 2 (A) – (C) show the catalytic activity of Y2O3 for the OCM reaction. CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity were linearly increased with increasing the reaction temperature. Among the catalysts tested here, Y2O3(P) showed the highest CH4 conversion, and CH4 conversion decreased in the order of Y2O3(P) > Y2O3(HT) ∼ Y2O3(RP) > Y2O3(HP). It is noteworthy that the same tendency was observed for NO decomposition reaction. As seen in Fig. 2(D), the highest NO decomposition activity was achieved on Y2O3(P), and the lowest active catalyst was Y2O3(HP). On the other hand, as seen in Fig. 2(B), C2 selectivity, which is the important guideline to determine the activity for the OCM reaction, was found to be inconsistent with CH4 conversion. Namely, Y2O3(HP), which is the lowest active catalyst for CH4 oxidation and NO decomposition, gave the highest C2 selectivity. This suggests that the active catalyst for NO decomposition is not necessarily active for the formation of C2 products (C2H6 and C2H4) in the OCM reaction. The distribution of actives sites for CH4 oxidation and C2 formation might not be uniform on the surface of Y2O3 prepared by different methods, resulting in the different catalytic behavior for the C2 formation in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. 3.2 OCM performance of Ba-doped Y2O3 In Table 2 are summarized the physico-chemical properties of Ba-doped Y2O3(P) catalysts. It appears that the BET surface area of Ba/Y2O3(P) was gradually decreased with an increase in the Ba loading. Since the crystallite size of Y2O3 was also increased with increasing Ba loading, Ba additive would promote the aggregation of Y2O3 particles. Fig. 3 (A) shows the XRD patterns of Ba/Y2O3(P) with different Ba loadings. In addition to the XRD peaks due to Y2O3, a weak but distinct XRD peaks ascribed to BaCO3 was detected when Ba loading was increased up to 5 wt%. It should be noted that the addition of 1 wt% Ba into Y2O3(P) caused a shift of XRD peaks due to Y2O3 toward lower angles (Fig. 3(B)), suggesting the formation of a solid solution in which Ba2+ ions are incorporated into Y2O3 lattice. This peak shift can be explained by the fact that the radius of Ba2+ ion (0.135 nm) is larger than that of Y3+ ion (0.09 nm). Since no further shift of XRD peaks was observed for the Ba/Y2O3(P) with Ba loading more than 5 wt%, a small amount of Ba2+ ions can substitute with Y3+ ions in Y2O3 lattice. As given in Fig. 4 (D), we confirmed that the addition of Ba into Y2O3(P) caused an enhancement of NO decomposition activity. Optimum Ba loading was found to be 5–10 wt%, in accordance with our previous report [19]. It should be noted that not only CH4 conversion but also C2 selectivity on Y2O3(P) for the OCM reaction was clearly increased by the addition of Ba (Figs. 4(A) and (B)). As seen in Fig. 4(C), the formation of C2 products was also increased with an increase in Ba loading up to 10 wt%. This is well consistent with the NO decomposition activity of Ba/Y2O3(P). 3.3 Surface state of Ba/Y2O3 by FT-IR: methanol adsorption Methanol adsorption was studied by IR spectroscopy on Ba-doped Y2O3(P) to gain information on the surface coordination state of Y2O3. It is well known that the exposure of methanol onto various oxides such as CeO2 [28–30], Al2O3 [31], Ga2O3 [32] and ZrO2 [33,34] gives rise to distinct IR bands assigned to the CO stretching modes of methoxy (OCH3) species in the range of 1200 – 950 cm−1. A few IR bands due to on-top, doubly and triply bridging species can be observed depending the coordination state of cations. Fig. 5 shows the IR spectra of the surface OCH3 species formed on Ba-doped Y2O3(P). It appears that Y2O3(P) showed the distinct IR band at 1082 cm−1 along with the shoulder bands at 1106 and 1050 cm−1 by methanol adsorption (Fig. 5(a)). Methoxy species formed on CeO2 with the cubic phase of which the crystal structure is the same as that of Y2O3 gave the IR bands at around 1100, 1080 and 1060 cm−1 assignable to the OCH3 species linearly bonded on Ce4+ sites, bridge-bonded on Ce3+ sites with oxygen vacancy and bridge-bonded on Ce4+ sites, respectively [28,34–36]. Therefore, IR bands observed for Y2O3(P) can be ascribed to the OCH3 species linearly bonded on Y3+ sites, bridge-bonded on Y3+ sites with oxygen vacancy and bridge-bonded on Y3+ sites from the higher wavenumber. As can be seen in Fig. 5, the addition of 1 wt% Ba into Y2O3 caused a decrease in the intensity of IR bands in the whole range, suggesting the coverage of Y2O3 surface by Ba species. It is of interest that the 1082 cm−1 band was slightly widened by the addition of 1 wt% Ba and then slightly shifted to 1080 cm−1 by an increase in the Ba loading. It is also noteworthy that the 1106 cm−1 band due to the on-top OCH3 species was diminished when Ba loading was increased up to 10 wt%. Taking into account the XRD results given in Fig. 3, the shift of the 1082 cm−1 band as well as the disappearance of the 1106 cm−1 band would be due to the creation of electron donor sites [28], which behave as basic sites, by a substitution of Ba2+ ions with Y3+ ions in Y2O3 lattice. 3.4 O/18O isotopic exchange reaction over Ba/Y2O3 Fig. 6 shows the profiles of 16O2 and 16O18O evolution and 18O2 consumption in the 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction over Y2O3(P) and Ba(10)/Y2O3(P). Both catalysts gave similar profiles for each O2 species. Namely, the evolution of 16O18O and the consumption of 18O2 were simultaneously observed, followed by the 16O2 evolution at higher temperature. Duprez et al. [37,38] reported similar 16O/18O isotopic exchange profiles for Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2 and MgO, and then proposed that the isotopic exchange reaction over the oxides takes place via the simple hetero-exchange mechanism, where the reaction between a molecule dioxygen (18O2) in gas phase and an atomic oxygen (16O) of the solid occurs: 18O2(g) + 16O(s) → 16O18O(g) + 18O(s). Therefore, the simple hetero-exchange mechanism is suspected to be favored on Y2O3 irrespective of Ba additive. Fig. 7 shows the comparison of the 16O18O and 16O2 evolution and the 18O2 consumption behavior over Ba-doped Y2O3(P). It appears that the addition of Ba into Y2O3 caused a shift of light-off temperature at which the evolution of 16O18O and the consumption of 18O2 were initiated, indicating an increase in the activity of Y2O3 for the 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction. The light-off temperature was gradually decreased with an increase in Ba loading up to 10 wt%, and then significant change was no longer observed for Ba(15)/Y2O3(P). 4 Discussion The objective of this work is to reveal the similarity of catalytically active site for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions, and to propose new insights into the strategy for producing the OCM catalysts. As for the OCM reaction, oxygen species such as O−, O2 −, O2- and O2 2- formed on the catalyst surface has been well established to play an important role in the activation of CH4 molecule to form CH3· radical intermediate [4,5,39–41]. The direct participation of O− and/or O2 2- species was spectroscopically and kinetically confirmed by some researchers [1,10,42–45]. On the other hand, Lunsford et al. [22,46] proposed the reaction mechanism in which NO2 − species formed via the oxidation of NO by O− and/or O2- act as an intermediate in NO decomposition over Ba/MgO. Namely, effective oxygen species for CH4 activation, leading to the formation of CH3· radical intermediate, seem to be not quite the same as that for NO activation. Since oxygen activation takes place via the adsorption on the catalyst surface, the types of oxygen species created on the surface is suspected to be strongly dependent on the surface characteristics such as morphology, coordination state, crystal structure, particle size and so on. We first prepared Y2O3, which is known to show the activity for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions, by employing various methods, and then compared the catalytic activity for both reactions. As can be seen in Fig. 2, relatively good correlation between CH4 conversion in the OCM reaction and NO conversion in NO decomposition was observed. Boreskov [17] revealed the similarity of the catalytic activity of the 4th period transition metal oxides for NO decomposition and CH4 oxidation. In agreement with Boreskov’s report, the active catalyst for NO decomposition was found to be also active for CH4 oxidation in the OCM reaction, indicating the similarity of the catalytically active sites for the activation of CH4 and NO molecules. However, C2 selectivity as an important guideline for the OCM reaction is not consistent with NO conversion. This is probably because the surface morphological properties are not uniform for each Y2O3. As summarized in Table 1, the BET surface area of Y2O3(RP) and Y2O3(HT) was found to be much smaller than the surface area evaluated from the crystallite size. Taking into account the fact that Y2O3 possesses a C-type cubic structure with oxygen defect sites [47,48] on which oxygen activation takes places, different types of oxygen species may be formed on the surface of each Y2O3, leading to the difficulty to understand the similarity of active sites for the C2 formation in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. Since the distribution of actives sites for CH4 oxidation and C2 formation might not be uniform on the surface of Y2O3 prepared by different methods, the similarity of the active sites for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions was investigated on Ba-doped Y2O3(P) catalysts, which are active for the former [49] and latter reactions [18–21]. As can be seen in Fig. 4, the addition of Ba into Y2O3(P) caused an enhancement of not only NO decomposition activity but also CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity. Optimum Ba loading was found to be 5–10 wt%. Fig. 8 shows the relationship between the C2 yield in OCM activity and the NO decomposition activity of Ba/Y2O3(P) catalysts at 750 °C. In contrast from the case of Y2O3, a good correlation was observed for both reactions. This indicates that our research strategy, that is, the similarity of the active sites for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions, is not doubt. Here, the role of Ba species in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions should be discussed. Alkaline earth oxides are known to possess the ability for the activation of O2 molecule on the surface because of their electron-donating ability [38]. Low coordinated M2+O2− pair sites are believed to play a beneficial role in O2 activation [50]. In this study, we performed the 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction to clarify if Ba species can promote the O2 activation. As can be seen in Fig. 7, the addition of Ba into Y2O3 caused a significant shift of light-off temperature for the formation of 16O18O toward lower temperature region, indicating that Ba species promotes the O2 activation. It should be noted that the order of the light-off temperature on Ba/Y2O3 is well consistent with those of the C2 yield for the OCM reaction and the NO decomposition activity (Fig. 8). Therefore, the active sites on which the O2 activation takes place would also play a beneficial role in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. Kaminski et al. [49] performed XPS and XAFS analyses of Ba-doped Y2O3 as the OCM catalyst, and proposed that the charge-deficient oxygen sites created by the substitution of Y3+ lattice sites with Ba2+ act as catalytically active sites. Au et al. [51] also reported that the addition of BaF2 into Y2O3 can efficiently promote the OCM reaction by increasing the hydrogen abstraction from CH4 molecule. Taking into account the suggestions by Kaminski et al. and Au et al., the interface between Y2O3 and Ba is suspected to behave as active sites in the OCM reaction. In the present study, we observed a shift of XRD peaks due to Y2O3 by addition of Ba (Fig. 3), suggesting a substitution of Ba2+ ions with Y3+ ions in Y2O3 lattice. In other words, the creation of the interface with strong interaction between Ba and Y2O3 is suspected. We also performed FT-IR spectroscopy following methanol adsorption, and observed the disappearance of the 1106 cm−1 band as well as the shift of the 1082 cm−1 band by addition of Ba into Y2O3 (Fig. 5). Considering the band assignments for the former one to the on-top OCH3 species on Y3+ sites and the latter one to the bridge-bonded OCH3 species on Y3+ sites with oxygen vacancy, the oxygen-deficient Y3+ sites with high electron-donating ability would be created on the surface of Y2O3 by interacting with Ba. On the basis of XRD, FT-IR spectroscopy and 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction, we conclude that the oxygen-deficient Y3+ sites interacting strongly with Ba play a beneficial role in O2 activation, leading to the activation of CH4 and NO molecules to form intermediate in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. 5 Conclusions Y2O3 prepared by different methods catalyzed the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). Among the catalysts tested here, Y2O3 prepared by precipitation method using ammonia as precipitant showed the highest CH4 conversion. A good correlation between CH4 conversion and NO decomposition activity was also confirmed for Y2O3 catalysts, suggesting the similarity of active sites for CH4 oxidation and NO decomposition reactions. Since Y2O3 prepared by homogeneous precipitation method, which is the lowest active catalyst for CH4 oxidation and NO decomposition, gave the highest C2 selectivity, the active catalyst for NO decomposition is not necessarily active for the formation of C2 products (C2H6 and C2H4) in the OCM reaction. The addition of Ba into Y2O3 prepared by precipitation method caused a significant increase in CH4 conversion as well as C2 selectivity for the OCM reaction. In accordance with our previous reports, Ba/Y2O3 effectively catalyzed NO decomposition reaction. The order of the C2 yield for the OCM reaction over Ba/Y2O3 with different Ba loading was in good agreement with that for the NO decomposition, suggesting the similarity of the active sites for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. XRD and FT-IR spectroscopy following methanol adsorption revealed that the addition of Ba into Y2O3 can create the oxygen-deficient Y3+ sites with high electron-donating ability via a substitution of Ba2+ ions with Y3+ ions in Y2O3 lattice. Ba/Y2O3 was also found to effectively catalyze the 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction in the lower temperature region compared with Y2O3. The oxygen-deficient Y3+ sites interacting strongly with Ba was concluded to play a beneficial role in O2 activation, leading to the activation of CH4 and NO molecules to form intermediate in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. coredata.dc:description: A similarity of catalytically active sites for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) and NO decomposition was investigated. Y2O3 prepared by different methods showed the activity for both reactions. However, no good correlation between the C2 (C2H6 and C2H4) yield for the OCM reaction and the NO decomposition activity was observed. Since the disagreement of the catalytic activity for both reactions was suspected to be due to the non-uniform surface morphological properties of Y2O3, detail experiments were performed for Ba-doped Y2O3 catalysts. It was noteworthy that the addition of Ba into Y2O3 prepared by precipitation method caused a significant increase in not only the C2 yield for the OCM reaction but also the NO decomposition activity. The order of the C2 yield for the OCM reaction over Ba/Y2O3 with different Ba loading was in good agreement with that for the NO decomposition, suggesting the similarity of the active sites for the OCM and NO decomposition reactions. XRD, FT-IR spectroscopy following methanol adsorption and 16O/18O isotopic exchange reaction revealed that the oxygen-deficient Y3+ sites interacting strongly with Ba play a beneficial role in O2 activation, leading to the activation of CH4 and NO molecules to form intermediate in the OCM and NO decomposition reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidative coupling of methane over Ba-doped Y2O3 catalyst—Similarity with active site for direct decomposition of NO
